description: From Middle English doun, from Old English dūne, aphetic form of adūne, from ofdūne (“off the hill”). For the development from directional phrases to prepositions, compare Middle Low German dāle (“(in/to the) valley”), i.e. "down(wards)".

adjectives.description: down (comparative more down, superlative most down)

entries.meaning: Facing downwards.
examples: Turn the cloth over so that the patterned side is down.

entries.meaning: At a lower level than before.
examples: The stock market is down.
Prices are down.

entries.meaning: (informal) Sad, unhappy, depressed, feeling low.
examples: Mary seems very down since she split up with her boyfriend.

entries.meaning: (normally in the combination 'down with') Sick or ill.
examples: He is down with the flu.

entries.meaning: (not comparable, military, law enforcement, slang, of a person) Wounded and unable to move normally, or killed.
examples: We have an officer down outside the suspect's house.
There are three soldiers down and one walking wounded.

entries.meaning: (not comparable, military, aviation, slang, of an aircraft) Mechanically failed, collided, shot down, or otherwise suddenly unable to fly.
examples: We have a chopper down near the river.

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Inoperable; out of order; out of service.
examples: The system is down.

entries.meaning: Having a lower score than an opponent.
examples: They are down by 3–0 with just 5 minutes to play.
He was down by a bishop and a pawn after 15 moves.
At 5–1 down, she produced a great comeback to win the set on a tiebreak.

entries.meaning: (baseball, cricket, colloquial, following the noun modified) Out.
examples: Two down and one to go in the bottom of the ninth.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, with "on") Negative about; hostile to.
examples: Ever since Carter, I've been down on Democrats.

entries.meaning: (Canada, US, slang) Comfortable with, accepting of.
examples: He's chill enough; he'd probably be totally down with it.
Are you down to hang out at the mall, Jamal?
As long as you're down with helping me pick a phone, Tyrone.

entries.meaning: (African-American Vernacular, slang) Accepted, respected, or loyally participating in the (thug) community.
examples: What you mean, 'No'? Man, I thought you was down.

entries.meaning: Finished (of a task); defeated or dealt with (of an opponent or obstacle); elapsed (of time). Often coupled with to go (remaining).
examples: Two down and three to go.
Ten minutes down and nothing's happened yet.

entries.meaning: Thoroughly practiced, learned or memorised; mastered. (Compare down pat.)
examples: It's two weeks until opening night and our lines are still not down yet.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Downright; absolute; positive.
(of a tree, limb, etc) Fallen or felled.
examples: Will you please let me get two loads of down wood.

adverbs.description: down (not generally comparable, comparative farther down, superlative farthest down)

entries.meaning: (comparable) From a higher position to a lower one; downwards.
examples: The cat jumped down from the table.

entries.meaning: (comparable) At a lower or further place or position along a set path.
examples: His place is farther down the road.
The company was well down the path to bankruptcy.

entries.meaning: As a down payment.
examples: You can have it, no money down.

entries.meaning: On paper (or in a durable record).
examples: You need to write down what happened while it's still fresh in your mind.

entries.meaning: To the south (as south is at the bottom of typical maps).
examples: I went down to Miami for a conference.

entries.meaning: Away from the city (regardless of direction).
examples: He went down to Cavan.
down on the farm
down country

entries.meaning: At or towards any place that is visualised as 'down' by virtue of local features or local convention, or arbitrarily, irrespective of direction or elevation change.
examples: She lives down by the park.

entries.meaning: (sports) Towards the opponent's side (in ball-sports).
Into a state of non-operation.
examples: The computer has been shut down.
They closed the shop down.

entries.meaning: To a subordinate or less prestigious position or rank.
examples: Smith was sent down to the minors to work on his batting.
After the incident, Kelly went down to Second Lieutenant.

entries.meaning: (rail transport) In the direction leading away from the principal terminus, away from milepost zero.
(sentence substitute, imperative) Get down.
examples: Down, boy! (such as to direct a dog to stand on four legs from two, or to sit from standing on four legs.)

entries.meaning: (UK, academia, dated) Away from Oxford or Cambridge.
examples: He's gone back down to Newcastle for Christmas.

entries.meaning: From a remoter or higher antiquity.
examples: These traditions have been handed down over generations.

entries.meaning: So as to lessen quantity, level or intensity.
examples: You need to tone down the rhetoric.
Please turn the music down!

entries.meaning: So as to reduce size, weight or volume.
examples: Trim the stick down to a length of about twelve inches.
Thanks to my strict diet, I've slimmed down to eleven stone.
Boil the mixture down to a syrupy consistency.

entries.meaning: From less to greater detail.
examples: This spreadsheet lets you drill down to daily or even hourly sales figures.

entries.meaning: So as to secure or compress something to the floor, ground, or other (usually horizontal) surface.
examples: We need to nail down this carpet so people don't keep tripping over it.

entries.meaning: Used with verbs to indicate that the action of the verb was carried to some state of completion, permanence, or success rather than being of indefinite duration.
examples: He closed operations. / He closed down operations.
He chased answers. / He chased down answers.

entries.meaning: Forward, straight ahead.
examples: At the first intersection turn left and walk down, then turn right.

entries.meaning: A negative aspect; a downer, a downside.
examples: I love almost everything about my job. The only down is that I can't take Saturdays off.

entries.meaning: (dated) A grudge (on someone).
examples: She had a down on me. I don't know what for, I'm sure; because I never said a word.

entries.meaning: An act of swallowing an entire drink at once.
(American football) A single play, from the time the ball is snapped (the start) to the time the whistle is blown (the end) when the ball is down, or is downed.
examples: I bet after the third down, the kicker will replace the quarterback on the field.

entries.meaning: (crosswords) A clue whose solution runs vertically in the grid.
examples: I haven't solved 12 or 13 across, but I've got most of the downs.

entries.meaning: A downstairs room of a two-story house.
examples: She lives in a two-up two-down.

entries.meaning: Down payment.
The lightest quark with a charge number of −1⁄3.
From the higher end to the lower of.
examples: The ball rolled down the hill.

entries.meaning: From north to south of.
examples: We sailed down the eastern seaboard.

entries.meaning: From one end to another of (in any direction); along.
examples: The bus went down the street.
They walked down the beach holding hands.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) At (a given place that is seen as removed from one's present location or other point of reference).
examples: I'll see you later down the pub.

verbs.description: down (third-person singular simple present downs, present participle downing, simple past and past participle downed)

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To knock (someone or something) down; to cause to come down; to fell. [from 16th c.]

entries.meaning: (transitive) Specifically, to cause (something in the air) to fall to the ground; to bring down (with a missile etc.). [from 19th c.]
examples: The helicopter was downed by a surface-to-air missile.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lower; to put (something) down. [from 16th c.]
examples: The bell rang for lunch, and the workers downed their tools.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To defeat; to overpower. [from 17th. c.]
(transitive, colloquial) To disparage; to put down. [from 18th c.]
examples: ‘I remember how you downed Beauclerk and Hamilton, the Wits, once at our House, – when they talked of Ghosts.’

entries.meaning: (intransitive, rare or obsolete) To go or come down; to descend. [from 17th. c.]
(transitive, colloquial) To drink or swallow, especially without stopping before the vessel containing the liquid is empty. [from 19th c.]
examples: He downed an ale and ordered another.

entries.meaning: (transitive, American football, Canadian football) To render (the ball) dead, typically by touching the ground while in possession. [from 19th c.]
examples: He downed it at the seven-yard line.

entries.meaning: (transitive, golf, pocket billiards) To sink (a ball) into a hole or pocket. [from 20th c.]
examples: He downed two balls on the break.

description: From Middle English doune, from Old English dūn, from Proto-Germanic *dūnaz, *dūnǭ (“sandhill, dune”), probably borrowed from Proto-Celtic *dūnom (“hill; hillfort”) (compare Welsh din (“hill”), Irish dún (“hill, fort”)), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰewh₂- (“to finish, come full circle”). Cognate with West Frisian dún (“dune, sandhill”), Dutch duin (“dune, sandhill”), German Düne (“dune”). More at town; akin to dune.  Doublet of Down.

entries.meaning: (especially southern England) A hill, especially a chalk hill; rolling grassland
examples: We went for a walk over the downs.
The North Downs are a ridge of chalk hills in south east England.

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural) A field, especially one used for horse racing.
(UK, chiefly in the plural) A tract of poor, sandy, undulating or hilly land near the sea, covered with fine turf which serves chiefly for the grazing of sheep.

description: From Middle English doun, from Old Norse dúnn, from Proto-Germanic *dūnaz (“down”), which is related to *dauniz (“(pleasant) smell”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰowh₂-nis, from the root *dʰewh₂-.
Cognate with Saterland Frisian Duune (“fluff, down”), German Daune (“down”) and Danish dun (“down”).

entries.meaning: Soft, fluffy immature feathers which grow on young birds. Used as insulating material in duvets, sleeping bags and jackets.
(botany) The pubescence of plants; the hairy crown or envelope of the seeds of certain plants, such as the thistle.
The soft hair of the face when beginning to appear.
That which is made of down, as a bed or pillow; that which affords ease and repose, like a bed of down.

verbs.description: down (third-person singular simple present downs, present participle downing, simple past and past participle downed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cover, ornament, line, or stuff with down.
